addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lordes,
e Lordes and others of her
Ma
ties
privy Councel
.

10 Ja
n
1591.
M
r
Bodeleie to
e LL
. The dealinge w
th
e States uppon
eir LL
l
re
s for
e Musteringe of
e English bandes./

page.lettertext:
fol.13r
May it please yo
r
good LL. to be adverti-
sed that yo
r
letters bearing date
e 19 of
De
c
were delivered unto me
e 7 of this
present: by w
ch
yo
r
LL. doe require, that
this
Councel of state
should be moved, to ap-
point some Officers of theirs, to passe a present
Muster of all her Ma
ties
forces in these contreis
and to doe it heereafter every moneth, or as
oft as they see cause, for suche special occasi-
ons as yow have willed me to signifie.
For
e effecting of that, w
ch
is desired
by yo
r
LL. I have taken suche order, though
it be not in suche forme, as is specified in yo
r
letter, as I trust yo
r
LL. will allowe.
For it may please yow to calle to minde, for
e mater of Musters of
e Englishe forces,
there was never as yet any order taken,
at
was established w
t
mutual consent both of her
Ma
tie
and
e states, and jointly observed aswell
by
e
Dutche
as by
e Englishe Commissaries.
They have alwaies rejected
e dead paies
of every Company, and made exceptions to di-
vers pointes of her Ma
ties
discipline: as
M
r
Wilkes
can relate to yo
r
LL. at large, and
is expressely signified in their last Apostilles
to his Propositions. In consideration wherof
if they should be nowe requested in
e name of
her Ma
tie
and so from time to time heereafter,
to proceede to
e mustering of
e Englishe com-
panies w
t
their owne Commissaries, and they
permitted, as they have alwaies pretended,
and shall also nowe be charged by
e Counsel of state,
fol.13v
to conclude
e dead paies w
t
e rest of the
checkes, I am certainly persuaded that they
will alleage it, when time is, to her Ma
ties
pre-
judice, and make it an argument, to prove her
approbation of their Musters. To prevent
the worst of this scruple, I have declared heere
unto them, but all
as
of my self, and not directed
by her Ma
tie
that I am charged by yo
r
LL.
being greatly displeased w
t
e weakenes of
e
Englishe Enseignes, w
ch
were drawen from hens
for
e siege of
Rouen
, and fearing
at
e rest are
maintened no better, to informe my self by all
good meanes of
e state and strength of every
bande: to the
ir
ende there might be some order
for their further renforcing, and for keeping them
heereafter in some better condition. For mine
owne particular I lette them understand, that
I had no kinde of meanes to give yo
r
LL. an
assured notice of that whiche was required.
For if I grownded on reportes, I might happely
offer wronge to
e Captaines, and abuse yo
r
LL
w
t
uncertaintie. And to take information
from
e Englishe Commissaries, I thought an im-
perfect and deceatfull meanes, for
at it was
apparant that by them, and their voluntary
sufferance, or notorious negligence, those disor-
ders were growen. Wherupon I made re-
quest
at they would condescend, to send their
owne Commissaries to every suche place, where
the Englishe souldiers are in Garrison, and all
at one time, and upon
e soddaine to passe a
fol.14r
general Muster: for w
ch
I would write so ef-
fectually to
e Governo
rs
, Commissaries and other
Englishe Officers, as they should rather be as-
sisted then impeached, in
e execution of their
charge. And if they would permitte me
upon it, to take a transcript of their Rolles, I
would send them presently home, to be compa-
red w
t
e Englishe certificats, whereby their
abuses might be better evicted, and present
order taken for some special reformac
o
n: w
ch
would benefit this contrey as muche as her
Ma
tie
. To this demaunde they assented
very willingly, and are already preparing
to dispatche their Commissaries.
For as much as yo
r
LL. intention, to my
understanding, is aswell accomplished by
this course of dealing, as by a special Pro-
position in
e name of her Ma
tie
w
ch
I am
persuaded may prove prejudicial, I hope
yo
r
LL. of yo
r
goodnes will vouchesafe my
proceeding a favorable construction: and as
I finde it doth stand w
t
yo
r
honorable liking,
I will
deale
of my self to persuade them heereafter
to a monethly, or rather to a more uncertaine
time of taking soddaine Musters, wherto I
make account they will be easely drawen,
in case they finde it is a meanes, to redresse
those abuses of
e Englishe Officers.
And
thus attending most humbly yo
r
LL. further
pleasure, I take my humble leave.
From
e
Hage
. Ja
n
10 1591.
Yo
r
LL. most humble to commaund Tho. Bodley
